Award.AwardTitle: Molecular Interactions of the Bacterial Actin, MreB

Division.LongName: Div Of Molecular and Cellular Bioscience

Award.AbstractNarration:
Intellectual Merit
Nearly all cells use an internal scaffolding system known as a cytoskeleton to control cell shape. The proteins that comprise this system have been known and well studied in large, complex eukaryotic cells for many decades, but were unknown in bacteria until only very recently. This project represents the first concerted attempt to characterize the bacterial actin-based cytoskeleton at the level of protein-protein interactions. It builds on a rich history of cytoskeletal research on eukaryotic cells and bridges the gap between the mature eukaryotic cytoskeleton field and the newly developing body of work addressing the basic cell biology of bacteria. It employs novel imaging techniques with established and new biochemical and biophysical approaches to address the means by which the proteins that comprise the bacterial cytoskeleton carry out their physiological roles and ultimately affect cellular behavior.

Broader Impact
This project will broadly impact education and training; it will support outreach; and will benefit society scientifically. From the perspective of education and training, the majority of the proposed experiments will be carried out by graduate students. Indeed students will play an integral role in the intellectual development of all stages of the project, from developing and testing hypotheses to publication. Traditionally, all members of the PI's laboratory attend weekly laboratory meetings and journal clubs at which each member presents recent results and a paper from the literature. In support of outreach activities the PI will join a team of scientists at the University of Wisconsin-Madison who promote the development of interest in science for students in local K-12 schools. The PI's involvement in this Center for Biological Education will bring hands-on biological microscopy to local K-12 students to supplement the level of instruction available at the public schools. Students will be engaged in science modules based on optical microscopy as a part of after school programs, Saturday morning programs at local libraries, and/or Saturday morning programs at the University of Wisconsin-Madison. The scientific benefit to society of this project is reflected in the understanding that the existence of prokaryotic actins provides new perspectives on the evolution of the cytoskeleton, but just as importantly provides new reagents and the ability to test new hypotheses about the mechanisms of filament assembly and regulation. Identified structural, functional and sequence differences between prokaryotic and eukaryotic actins will provide insight into the limitations and range of functions of this important molecule. Additionally, knowledge gained toward these aims will significantly influence perspectives of the roles of actin in eukaryotic cell motility and cell division.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Project Outcomes Report

Award 0818946

Molecular Interactions of the Bacterial Actin, MreB

Principal Investigator: Kurt J. Amann

University of Wisconsin-Madison

Period of support: 12/15/2008 to 11/30/2014

This NSF award has been critical to my development as a scientist and educator, as well as to the advancement of our knowledge of how protein complexes assemble; how cells control their shape; and how these two processes have complemented and interacted each other over evolutionary history. The award supported five undergraduate, and five graduate students, and led to the publication of two papers and numerous abstracts and posters at national meetings. It also supported my laboratory during my transition to independence and my promotion to a tenured position.

The work supported by the award is concerned with proteins that assemble into linear filaments that are used by cells to control their shapes, their movements, and the localization of other molecules inside the cell. At the onset of the project, much was known about how these cytoskeletal proteins behaved in eukaryotic cells, but they had only recently been observed in bacteria and we knew almost nothing about how the bacterial versions worked and what purpose they served in the cells, which have very different mechanical and structural properties from eukaryotes. Our work was the first to document how these bacterial cytoskeletal proteins assemble into polymers. We studied versions of the molecules from several different bacteria, and compared our findings to what we and others had learned over several decades of studying eukaryotes. What we learned was that evolution has very cleverly used two different families of cytoskeletal polymers in two very different ways in two differentkingdoms of life to do two very different tasks in two very different types of cells. In short, bacteria use actins to ensure that the cells produced by cell division each get a copy of the genetic material, while eukaryotes use tubulins to perform this task. Similarly, prokaryotes use tubulins to carry out the division of the cell itself, while eukaryotes useactins for this task. But because both prokaryotes and eukaryotes have both actins and tubulins, why has evolution switched their roles? I believe that the answer lies in how each molecule uses energy to control its assembly and to change its shape, and how these shape changes are affected by the size and physical constraints of the cell. In the future, I hope to be able to further test this hypothesis. If borne out, it will prove to be a fascinating example of how very small differences between closely related molecules can play enormously significant roles in the evolutionary history of life.

My work, as supported by this award, has carried over into the classroom, from undergraduate courses ranging from freshman biology to senior cell and molecular biology courses, to graduate seminars specializing in the cytoskeleton. Several thousand students have heard the story of this work, presented as an example of how studying the structure and interactions of molecules can help us understand how life on earth evolved.

My primary motivation in carrying out this work has been in its inherent scientific interest. Nonetheless, much of the work, including one of the publications supported by the award, involves studying how a drug interacts with and inhibits the assembly of bacterial actins, and causes cell death from a failure to divide. This is the kind of discovery that will be increasingly important as we exhaust the utility of conventional antibiotics.
